author: gcolvin
content:
Have we solved the access problem for Discord yet?

If I publish a web link to a conversation on our old Gitter channel people can read it without creating an account, and an account with Gitlab, Twitter, or Gitter is only needed to converse.

If I publish a link to a conversation here people seem to be forced to create a Discord account even to read the conversation.  If so, I think that is an unacceptable reduction of access to and transparency of our deliberations.

author: sky.cactus
content: I thought someone created a matrix bridge or something?

author: sky.cactus
content: One could pretty easily write a mirror bot that just mirrored conversations to somewhere like IPFS.  Maybe one file per day per channel with anchors for each message?  Bot could also have an in-chat command to get a permalink to any given message.

author: sky.cactus
content: I don't know if anyone has done that work though.

author: gcolvin
content: I wouldn't know how, but the current situation isn't good.  Especially the next time we make a controversial decision and people want to know why they weren't informed of the discussion or able to participate in time.

author: gcolvin
content: This is probably an issue for the entire Eth R&D  server.  A supposedly open project "hiding" in a proprietary system.  I noticed this today trying to read the discussion from one of my own computers where I had no access to my password manager.

author: sky.cactus
content: This would be a good project for a grant I think.  Discord has an API that is pretty easy to use and the technical expertise required is fairly low.  Writing auditable code is probably the hardest part.
